MISCELLE
The Reorganisation of the Roman Government in 366 B.  C. 
Obiter dictum in : Kurt von Fritz
After pointing out that,  irrespective of the struggles of patricians and plebeians,  Rome's expansion and the frequent conduct of several neous military operations would in any case have called for the existence of » more than two commanders - in - chief,  especially since their commanders - in - chief had also to attend to the distribution of justice and civil stration«,  Dr.  von Fritz remarks »The Athenians of the fifth century,  ybr the same reasons^ had ten highest commanders « ( my italics ). 
In fact,  as Dr.  von Fritz would doubtless have remembered had he been concerning himself at the moment with Greek history,  the precise number of generals in imperial Athens was the result of a chain of political accidents ; — of causes,  that is to say,  concerned not with military ments,  but with precisely what we are assured was not the prime cause of the reforms at Rome,  namely,  party politics.  Kleisthenes,  as the Athenaion Politeia informs us ( chap.  XXI,  4 ),  reformed the Athenian body politic on the basis of a ten - fold tribal system ; choosing this number,  rather than twelve,  because there were local political reasons against the latter number.  Some few years later { op.  cit.  ^ XXII ) ten strategoi were elected to command the contingents of the ten tribes,  under the annually elected commander - in - chief,  still called,  as from time immemorial,  the polemarch.  The army,  that is to say,  was ( perhaps only now ) reorganised on the basis of the Kleisthenic civil organisation. 
But in 487,  during the rise to power of Themistokles — whether or not at his instigation — came the great step towards democratization of the chief archonships,  including the polemarchy : the introduction of sortition among 500 elected candidates drawn from among the landed hippeis.  There is no reason to doubt that the supporters of this measure expected the average respectable »knights«,  thus raised to high command,  to take the major decisions in war,  with the advice of the elected strategoi serving under them.  The experiment is a deeply interesting one,  and reminiscent of the modern parliamentary practice of placing the ultimate control of armed forces in the hands of a civilian minister.
